PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. We reject in principle the need for a national I.D. card on the basis that it will be a gross violation of individual liberty.
2. We reject the notion that the government can claim a mandate for the proposed legislation and state categorically it does not reflect our will.
3. We believe that, as with the proposed Bill of Rights legislation, the government's methods and arguments in promoting this legislation have been under-handed and undemocratic.

4. We believe as a matter of faith and judgment that the proposed legislation is anti-God and that its implementation will result in further attacks on individual freedom and responsibility, the family and the Church and that the real intent is the promotion of a powerful secular humanist ``big brother'' government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should together with the House of Representatives take action to reject this proposed legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Clerk of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
An ID Card numbering system for all Australians would give future governments tremendous power to collect sensitive information and use it against us.

Criminal elements could benefit by forging cards and documents needed to obtain them, or by illegally accessing the data in the system. The dangers are much greater than with current systems such as Medicare, as the Australia Card number could link so many different confidential records.
The cost to government and private enterprise of implementing the ID Card would be enormous, outweighing any gains. Tax cheats can be stopped more effectively by better checks in the present system.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will reject the Australia Card Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

We the undersigned,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHANEY

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, from 51 citizens, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: A group of citizens has joined together to express publicly their deep concern about the Federal Government plan to introduce the Australia Card. The Group is diverse in background, occupation and political belief.
Each of the persons who has signed this declaration sought to awaken in the public mind an awareness of the long-term dangers of the national identity card system as proposed.

It must be understood that the Australia Card is not simply an identification card system-it involves the collection, compilation, recording and assessment of information on the activities of every individual Australian.
This system has never before been proposed in a free country in the form and extent now proposed for Australia, indeed, the U.S.A. has specifically rejected a similar identification card scheme.

It is intrusive, expensive, inconvenient and will not fulfil the expectation of its proponents who propose to employ a further 2,000 civil servants and who say the system will run at a loss for four years. Neither the Federal Police not the Department of Social Security have supported the scheme.
In acting to bring in this system the Government is acting against the majority report of an all-Party Select Committee of Parliament.
It is beyond the Constitutional power of the Commonwealth to impose directly a requirement to have a card.

Although there are provisions which avoid imposing an obligation to apply for the Card, this means nothing when the Card must be used for all employment, banking, medical and property transactions. The simple act of taking or continuing a job will be unlawful without the card. (Penalty up to $20,000).

We express our deep concern that the Government proposes to require all Australians to establish identity through a national, centralised, computerised identification system which will additionally involve the collection of information about individual Australians, and the assessment and use of that information for Government purposes:
that it is effectively compulsory;
that it denies economic freedom;
that it invades privacy;

the effect of the Bill as proposed is that all Australians who wish to be employed or hold a bank or building society account must attend on the Government to be photographed and then prove their identity;
that to the numbers of dole cheats and social security frauds will be added the card forgers and duplicators;

that its principle impact will be on the lives of ordinary, decent, honest Australians and the cost and inconvenience to government, business and individuals will far outweigh any potential revenue gains;

that it reverses the founding principle of a free society in that it makes the innocent individual accountable to the state, instead of the state being accountable to the collection of individuals in it;
that it assumes the benevolence of Government against the overwhelming historical evidence that individual liberty is only maintained through the control of the power of the state;
that future denial of the card will be a weapon available for the exercise of power over individuals, groups and those who disagree with the government of the time;
that the available alternatives to eliminate fraud against the revenue and the taxpayers should be considered and where appropriate pursued.

Those who have signed this Declaration have done so freely and to express their concern regardless of short-term political considerations, and invite others of like mind to join in signing and supporting this document.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and follows the question, not answered by the Minister, asked by Senator Lewis a few minutes ago. I remind the Minister that in September of 1986 he was prepared to advise manufacturers to rely on a dollar of somewhere over US60c in value, that just a few weeks ago we were presented with a Budget predicated on a dollar value of somewhere around US72c, and that at the beginning of this month he was prepared to say that he was hopeful that the dollar would follow the course of going down to 65c to 68c over the next few months. I remind him of that recent history because of the non-answer he gave to Senator Lewis. I also remind the Minister that the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia (MTIA) says in its latest Economic Review:

QUESTION.PARA: It seems most probable that the Australian dollar will continue to strengthen against the US dollar, perhaps rising in due course to the 75-80 US cents range.

Does the Minister agree with the Metal Trades Industry Association? If the Association is correct, does he agree that in those circumstances the only means of maintaining the competitiveness of the manufacturing sector is a sharp restriction of unit labour costs?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is all sorts of speculation about the value of the dollar by groups and individuals in the community who are not operating in the market-place.
—Like yourself.

—Yes. Inevitably, such people will have views about this sort of thing. Let me say that the MTIA views might be right, and they might be wrong. The dollar having been floated, either thing is possible. But Senator Chaney then went on to ask me-and I take this to be the point of his question-whether, if the MTIA is right, in those circumstances the only way of maintaining Australia's international competitiveness is by reducing real unit labour costs. My answer to that question is no. The means of maintaining Australia's international competitiveness are quite wide and varied. Unit labour costs have a very important role in maintaining Australia's international competitiveness, and this Government has stressed that on a number of occasions. Indeed, its policies have been directed to that point in industrial relations matters. But a much wider variety of factors go to our international competitiveness, including things such as marketing skills and capacity, the quality of the products we produce and the service we can provide in relation to those products. I could go on and on. A whole range of factors determines competitiveness in various industries. The sole determinants of competitiveness are not exclusively the value of the dollar or the question of real unit labour costs. Those things have to be seen in the context of a much wider range of factors which influence one's international competitiveness. Let me say that the depreciation of the dollar in 1985 and 1986, for example, gave Australian manufacturers a sort of window of opportunity in relation to price competitiveness internationally. But price is not the sole determinant of international competitiveness, particularly in manufacturing.

—I ask a supplementary question. In regard to the Minister's reference to a window of opportunity having been opened up by the devaluation of the dollar, does he accept that if the dollar rises as predicted by the Metal Trades Industry Association, that window of opportunity will be closed, and, indeed, that it has already been partly closed by the fact that our nominal wages have risen faster since that time than those of our trading partners? Does he further agree, therefore, that if the dollar continues to appreciate, we need either a lift in productivity or a reduction in wages, and that, notwithstanding the various factors he talks about, we cannot escape the need to be more competitive by reducing our unit labour costs by one of those two means?

—That supplementary question is just a rephrased version of the main question which I was asked. I do not see it as a supplementary question at all. As I said in answering Senator Chaney's original question, the relevance of unit labour costs is of very significant importance in terms of maintaining international competitiveness. I should point out that that fact has been publicly recognised by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) in its document Australia Reconstructed. That is a very important recognition by the ACTU. Certainly wages are vitally relevant and productivity is relevant. There is a whole range of means of obtaining improved productivity, which I do not need to go into now but some of which I referred to before.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. ANSWER.PARA: . . . it is highly unlikely that Australia will be able to lift its net export performance by anything like 1.75 per cent . . .

. . . the Government's revenue estimates cannot be relied on. They too are far too high.
He added:
. . . the figures for unemployment benefit expenditure are predicated on an increase in unemployment which appears to be far too low . . .

As to the other matters raised by Senator Short, apart from the contribution of net exports to GDP growth, the fact is that revenue came in some $920m above the Budget estimate-not below the Budget estimate, as Senator Short had asserted. This is principally due to the base broadening measures associated with the Government's tax reform package having produced more revenue than the conservative estimates allowed at the time those measures were introduced. These are the very base broadening measures, and additional revenues of course, which the Opposition, during the election campaign, was pledged to repealing. It is not clear what the Opposition's position is now on those base broadening measures, but the Government and I welcome the apparent change of heart on those questions of some of the more responsible members of the Opposition. However, they are still obviously committed to assisting tax evaders.

The Budget outlays on unemployment benefits-again, Senator Short had asserted that the cost estimates were too low-came in $139m below the Budget estimate. So, the basic answer to the third part of Senator Short's question-should anybody take any notice of Senator Short-is no. On the basis of his record nobody should take much notice of him. I can understand why he was replaced by Senator Stone, as shadow finance spokesman, with the reservation that some of Senator Stone's predictions were not much better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to reports of an agreement between the United States Administration and the Canadian Government on a free trade plan to lower all trade barriers between those two countries. What are the implications of this agreement for Australia's current trade negotiations with the United States of America and Canada? What are the ramifications of the agreement for the Cairns group of free traders, of which Canada is a member? How will the agreement affect the stance and bargaining position of the free trade group during the current General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round of multilateral trade negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case, as reported, that Canada and the United States have reached agreement in principle on the terms of a Canada-United States free trade agreement (FTA). The President notified Congress on 4 October that he intends to enter into a free trade agreement with Canada on 2 January 1988, subject to Congressional approval and to successful completion of the negotiations. Congress, then, has 90 days from 4 October to approve or reject the FTA. Details of the FTA remain to be negotiated but the major elements are as follows: It will come into force on 1 January 1989. It involves the removal of all tariffs, including those on agriculture, between the two countries on or before 1 January 1998. Each country has agreed to exempt the other from restrictions under their respective meat import laws. The elimination by the United States of all restrictions on the enrichment of Canadian uranium is also a provision of the agreement. There is agreement to work together to eliminate all subsidies which distort agricultural trade. There is to be an elimination of discriminatory mark-ups in the Canadian market for wines and spirits. Finally, the agreement involves the establishment of a bilateral disputes settlement mechanism.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that both countries have reached an agreement on issues, particularly agriculture, which are so important to the Uruguay round of multilateral trade negotiations, as Senator Macklin indicated, is obviously a very positive step forward. The Australian Government has been following the FTA negotiations closely and will continue to do so. Australia has its own trade agreement with Canada and Australian officials have today had consultations with Canadian officials to ensure that Australia's trading interests are protected. Mr Duffy, in his recent visit to Canada and the United States, expressed to his respective counterparts the same concerns about the need to protect and develop Australia's trading interests in these markets. I should add that I think Mr Duffy is making a ministerial statement within the next few days in which, no doubt, he will expand on some of the themes I have addressed in this answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware that the Government of Nicaragua has implemented the first major requirement of the Central American peace plan, authorising the pro-Opposition daily newspaper La Prensa to renew publication without restriction? In light of this, will the Minister convey to the United States Government Australia's support for the Central American peace plan and encourage that Government to accept the plan?

—Yes, the Government is aware of the Nicaraguan Government having recently lifted all proscriptions on the publication of La Prensa, the major right wing newspaper in Managua. It has also allowed Radio Catolica to resume broadcasting. The lifting of bans forms part of the commitments given by all of the Central American governments, as part of the peace accord of 7 August, to restore democracy and basic political freedoms within 150 days. The Government has previously applauded that accord and now welcomes the removal of censorship on La Prensa and Radio Catolica. It hopes that the accord is successful and will lead to an easing of tension and conflict in the region. The United States is not a party to the 7 August agreement, but its support will be essential. The Administration has given the accord qualified support to date but has foreshadowed further assistance for the Contras. The Administration is well aware that this Government's views on Central America are not in alignment with theirs.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister agree that the recent upsurge in purchases of residential real estate in urban areas by non-Australians is a clear indication that by relative international standards the value of such assets at our current exchange rate for the Australian dollar is too low? Secondly, does the Minister also agree with his colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce that even at its current level-let alone any higher one-the value of the Australian dollar is uncomfortably high from the viewpoint of either the import competing industries or the primary and resource exporting industries? Is the Government aware of this fundamental dilemma in a dollar which is too high from one viewpoint and too low from another, which its policies over the past few years have created for it? How does the Government propose to go about resolving that fundamental dilemma?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the question invited me to do what Senator Button has just declined to do and what Senator Lewis, I think it is, in the forecast matter of public importance says should not be done; that is, to speculate about whether the value of the Australian dollar is where it ought to be, or whether it should be higher or lower. Like Senator Button, I do not intend to speculate about that here.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to purchases of real estate, it is my understanding that the buying pressure from overseas came principally, if not overwhelmingly, from Japan. I think there can be no reasonable doubt that the changes in the relative values of the Australian dollar and the Japanese yen have been a significant factor in that. Over the last 2 1/2 years the Australian-United States exchange rate has changed by about 15 per cent-that is, the value of the Australian dollar relative to the US dollar has fallen by about 15 per cent. The value of the Australian dollar relative to the Japanese yen has fallen by something more than 50 per cent; indeed, I think possibly closer to 60 per cent than 50 per cent. That enormous shift in the relative value of the yen and the Australian dollar is a function of the appreciation of the yen rather than the depreciation of the Australian dollar.

Senator Stone appears to believe that the Government should do something about that. Frankly, I do not know what the Australian Government, any Australian government, could do which would have a significant effect on the international value of the yen, since Australia is, although a significant trading nation, by no means as big a trading nation as Japan, West Germany, the United States and a number of other countries. So, I do not think there is very much at all we can do about that, even if the implication that we should try to do something about the value of the yen is correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the response that the Minister has just made-and, incidentally, I take the opportunity of correcting his--
—Order!

—I ask the Minister on what basis he puts forward the view that the only source of purchases of urban residential real estate is Japan. There is a great deal of evidence that New Zealanders are buying as much. In view of the Minister's inability to give an affirmative answer to the first of my questions to him, is he therefore suggesting that the Treasurer's action last week in forbidding such purchases was unnecessary? Clearly, if the answer to the question--
—Order! Senator Stone, would you ask your supplementary question?
—Is the Minister suggesting that the Treasurer's action last week was unnecessary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I distinctly did not say that the only source of overseas buying of Australian real estate was Japan. I believe I said that the principal, if not the overwhelming, buying pressure is coming from Japan, as I understand it. I said `as I understand it'. If there is evidence to the contrary, naturally I will look at that evidence. Some of us believe that Keynes was basically correct when, after having been asked, `If decisive evidence could be produced which contradicted your beliefs, what would you do?' he said, `I would change my beliefs. What would you do?'. Most of us belong to the Keynesian school, at least in that sense, although it was frequently alleged that a former Treasury Secretary did not support Keynes in that view or perhaps in a number of others.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the New Zealand dollar, if I remember correctly, the present exchange rate is about $NZ1.30 to $A1, which is about the same as it was when I was in New Zealand five years ago. So if it is correct that there is a significant interest in New Zealand in buying real estate in Australia it cannot be attributed to any significant extent to changes in the relative exchange rate-over the last five years, anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer and is also about a non-Keynesian. Did the Minister hear the honourable member for O'Connor, Mr Tuckey, being interviewed by Pru Goward on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Morning Show today? If so, can the Minister clarify whether Mr Tuckey's objection to a system requiring an employer to ascertain his employees' tax file numbers is inconsistent with present principles applied under the Income Tax Assessment Act?

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Senator Cook's question asks for an interpretation of a statement which was made not by a Government Minister or by anybody for whom the Minister has any degree of responsibility. It is not a matter which falls within the responsibility of the Minister in terms of the discharge of his ministerial responsibilities.
—The question deals at least with the taxation part of Senator Walsh's representation. I will allow the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard Mr Tuckey this morning on the Morning Show going on at great length. Despite his verbosity, it was not entirely clear precisely what Mr Tuckey would support or would not support, let alone what the Liberal Party of Australia would support or would not support. The present pay as you earn (PAYE) tax system requires employers, and has long required employers, to act to some extent as enforcers of the income tax system. They are required to deduct what is thought to be an appropriate amount from wages and salaries, pay that money to the Australian Taxation Office and notify the Office of the amounts deducted and the name of the employee to whom those payments have been made.

ANSWER.PARA: What the present arrangements do not do is require the employer, with the exception of one area, one special arrangement which I will refer to in a moment, to verify the accuracy of the name given or to supply the Taxation Office with the tax file number or alleged tax file number of the employee to whom the payments have been made. In other words, it would appear that Mr Tuckey seems to think that it is all right for an employer to supply a false name to the Taxation Office, but he is not so keen on an employer supplying a correct name. If I am wrong in making that assumption, I hope that Mr Tuckey will promptly correct me, but it seems to me that what Mr Tuckey is objecting to is any onus being imposed on employers to notify the Taxation Office of the tax file number of the employee to whom payments are made and on whose behalf an employer is required, under longstanding law, to deduct PAYE tax instalments. Without such verification or notification of a number to see whether such a number exists in the Taxation Office, it is impossible to stamp out tax evasion in the PAYE tax area. I would like to know whether it is the policy of the Opposition that employers must have no onus placed upon them to notify the Taxation Office of the tax file number allegedly belonging to the people whom they are employing.

The one exception that I mentioned earlier is the prescribed payments system, which does require a sub-contractor or contractor to provide a deduction variation form which includes the tax file number of the person to whom the payment is being made. If the employer fails to produce that form with a tax file number, then, by law, tax will be deducted at a higher rate. That system was first announced in the 1982 Budget by the then Treasurer. It was enacted by this Government, and since it has been enacted some 50,000 new file numbers have been established in the industries to which the prescribed payments system applies. The only logical deduction that one can make from that is that most of those 50,000 people were previously employed under false names and did not have any identity as far as the Taxation Office was concerned. In other words, they were right there into the cash economy and evading tax. Within the ambit of the prescribed payments system, about 50,000 tax evaders have been picked up. The objective of the Australia Card, or the second-best option which the Government is considering, is to pick up what is almost certainly a very much larger number of tax evaders. There is no way in which those tax evaders can be picked up unless there is a requirement on employers to notify the Taxation Office of the tax file number or some other, more reliable means of identifying the employee.

It has been suggested by a number of people, and this comes principally from Press reports, that, in respect of tax evaded on interest payments, there should be a withholding tax. In order to be fully effective, such a withholding tax would have to be applied at the maximum personal rate of 49c in the dollar, otherwise people could still be paying less than their proper amount of tax if they use a false identity. In other words, while it is technically feasible to ensure that there is no tax evasion on interest payments by imposing a withholding tax of 49c or 50c in the dollar, the effect of that would be to force tens of thousands of honest pensioners, for example, who have a few thousand dollars in a building society, to pay, in the first instance, half of that interest received as taxation, for the purpose of detecting taxation cheats who hold money in interest bearing accounts under false names.

Finally, the Sydney Morning Herald of 25 September prophesied in an editorial that there would be significant resistance from the Liberal Party of Australia to any measure that struck effectively at tax evasion-the reason for that being, according to the Sydney Morning Herald, that tax evaders comprise a significant part of the Liberal Party's natural constituency. Senator Chaney's notice of motion tends to confirm that. But before the Liberal Party follows Wilson Tuckey too far down the road of protecting the tax evaders, I give it a bit of well-meant advice. Mr Tuckey has a record already of abusing public office for personal gain, and I warn it that it would be most unwise to follow him very far down that road.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister has cast a gross reflection on a member in another place. I ask you to ask Senator Walsh to withdraw it.
—I ask Senator Walsh to withdraw that reference.
—Very well, I will withdraw it and think about tabling the file on the Carnarvon Shire Council.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. It follows his just concluded answer in which he misrepresented the Opposition with respect to various matters, including the tax file number. Is it a fact that access to an individual taxpayer's tax file number by persons other than the taxpayer and the Australian Taxation Office has already given rise to difficulties in tax administration? Does he agree that, for example, it resulted in the diversion of refund cheques which were payable to taxpayers to people who had access to numbers and used them to obtain the diversion of those refund cheques? Does the Minister accept that general access to tax file numbers can itself be a source of abuse of the tax system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know the purpose of this question-other than, as somebody behind me suggests, to lay a smokescreen to conceal the fact that the Liberal Party is behaving in accordance with its tradition, that is, protecting people who cheat on the tax system. Senator Chaney asserts that there have been abuses of tax file numbers under existing arrangements. I do not know whether there have been or not. I will check out the accuracy of his assertion with the Treasurer who in turn, I expect, will pass it on to the Commissioner of Taxation. I am not aware of that having happened, except under circumstances where it is provided for by law and might well have got people into trouble. For example, section 16 authorises the Taxation Commissioner to provide certain information to the Secretary to the Department of Social Security, and for very good reason. The provision of that information might well have got some particular people into trouble-the sort of people, I hasten to add, who ought to be in trouble and who got into trouble because they were caught cheating on the system. But if innocent parties have been harmed under existing arrangements that would have nothing to do with a system which required employers to notify-and the notification, one would think, would have to be prompt-the Taxation Office of the tax file numbers, or at least the alleged tax file numbers, of the people they employ.

ANSWER.PARA: If there is no such notification requirement-alternatively, I suppose, an employer could deduct PAYE tax at the maximum personal rate-obviously there is no effective means of preventing people holding jobs or receiving income in a number of different names. That is exactly what happens now. Senator Maguire-this was published last week-has an accountant friend who was approached by an individual asking him, as a registered tax accountant, to complete not only his tax return but his tax return plus five other tax returns with bodgie names, covering income that the same taxpayer had received. In other words, so far as the Taxation Office was aware, that particular person had six different tax file numbers and six different names.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Senator Maguire do about it?

—I would hope that the accountant dobbed in the individual taxpayer, but that is the accountant's concern, not Senator Maguire's. As one would expect, any friend of Senator Maguire's is an ethical person. This particular tax accountant told that tax cheat that he would not complete his returns on ethical and moral grounds; he refused to do it. I guess the tax cheat then went and found a Liberal Party accountant who did it with no trouble at all.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not really know the point of Senator Chaney's question except, as was suggested to me from behind, to throw up a smokescreen to conceal the fact that the Liberal Party is reverting to type-that is, protecting tax cheats. This morning Mr Tuckey asserted that--

TALK.START.PARA: —So is Peter Garrett; so is Bondy; so is Alan Jones.

—Just for the record, I acknowledge that interjection so that it will go down alongside the name of Senator Walters that Alan Bond, Alan Jones and Peter Garrett are tax evaders. I do not know whether they are, but Senator Walters is asserting that they are.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister continually misrepresents the position of the Opposition. He is now misrepresenting the position of Senator Walters. Those are quite clearly mischievous comments.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr Tuckey asserted that the Australian Taxation Office is always trying to get more power rather than enforcing the law. There is perhaps a grain of truth in that, because I recall that when various High Court decisions had made it virtually impossible to enforce the taxation law, over a period of many years the Taxation Commissioner wrote a series of increasingly desperate letters to the then Treasurer begging him to amend the Act. Of course, that finally culminated in the exposures in the McCabe-Lafranchi report on tax avoidance in Australia and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of widespread tax evasion centred around the bottom of the harbour activities.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of misrepresentation it is said that I have misrepresented the Liberal Party's view on stamping out tax evasion and in one sense I genuinely hope that I have; but my interpretation-and this is the most reasonable interpretation that anybody could come to-is that Mr Tuckey on behalf of the Liberal Party is asserting that it will not accept any system which requires an employer promptly to notify the Taxation Office of the tax file number of any employee on whose behalf the employer is making PAYE deductions. That is my understanding of what Mr Tuckey said. If that is wrong--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is wrong.

—I am told it is wrong. I would welcome a statement from Mr Howard, Mr Peacock, Senator Puplick or anyone else who likes to say that the Liberal Party will not oppose such a measure. I would welcome any such statement from the Opposition. But that is my understanding of the Opposition's view or policy, as expounded by Mr Tuckey. If that is indeed the Opposition's policy, and if it gets the Australian Democrats to tag along behind, at some time it will, in the Senate, strike another major blow protecting tax evaders as it has so often done in the past.

—Order! I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the presence in the senators' guests gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the Federal Republic of Germany led by the President of the Bundesrat, Dr Wallmann. On behalf of all senators I extend to you, Mr President, and to the delegation a warm welcome and I trust that your stay in Australia is a success.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review reporting that Tasmanian Premier Robin Gray had responded to opposition to his announcement that taxes on fuel and car registrations would rise by up to 17 per cent in the State Budget by saying that the `hard decision' of raising State taxes and charges `had to be made because of a decline in Federal allocations'. Is resolution of the Tasmanian Government's financial problems a matter which only the Federal Government can address?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to that question has to be no. It is not really a matter for the Federal Government. Indeed, Tasmania continues to receive per capita payments from the Commonwealth Government vastly in excess of those received by any other State. I do not have the precise figures in front of me but I think they are some 30 per cent higher than the highest of the other five States on a per capita basis and close to 50 per cent higher than the average of all the other States. So Tasmania is treated advantageously so far as the Commonwealth Budget is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: As to how the Tasmanian Government should address its financial problems, if there are any, I suggest that the Premier look at the report at the end of last month of the Tasmanian Auditor-General, Mr David Kirby. A summary of that report appeared in the Mercury on 1 October. It referred, among other things, to financial mismanagement in some State Government departments, lower priority being given to inventory control and failure to comply with Treasury instructions. The article said:
Mr Kirby highlighted the Mines Department's accounting methods as particularly bad. One company had made a royalty return of $292,003 but had not made a payment until questioned by auditors.

The company had put in a return which showed a liability of $292,000, but the Tasmanian Administration was apparently so slothful that no demand was made for payment until the Auditor-General picked up the fact that what was effectively the bill had not been paid. The article also said:
Several companies had not paid royalties and no action had been taken.
It then referred to a new computer coming on line for the Retirement Benefits Fund, the State superannuation scheme, with none of the necessary checks being taken.

I could go on, but it is very clear-and that was not an accusation by the Federal Government or even by any of its agencies, but by the State's own Auditor-General-that there is a severe lack of fiscal control within the Tasmanian Administration. I suggest that Mr Gray should look to that before he starts complaining, quite unjustifiably, that Tasmania has in some way been treated harshly by the Commonwealth Government when, in fact, on a per capita basis, Tasmania receives far more from the Commonwealth Government than does any other State.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SECURITY AND ARMS CONTROL IN THE NORTH PACIFIC

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, concerns the potential for discussions on security and arms control in the North Pacific, with reference to the Foreign Minister's speech at the Australian National University (ANU) conference on that subject on 12 August. Given the increasing naval build-up in the North Pacific in the last few years by both the United States of America and the Soviet Union, and the destabilising nature of the United States maritime strategy, why is the Government apparently not prepared to act on some of the suggestions put forward by Mr Hayden at the ANU conference? What was the relevance of some of the constructive ideas floated by Mr Hayden, such as putting a ceiling on, or reducing, strategic nuclear weapons, limiting naval forces in the North Pacific, imagining various naval disengagement arrangements, or looking into the concept of a nuclear free zone, if the Government was not prepared to raise them with the regional powers involved, particularly those with whom Mr Hayden noted we have close connections in terms of trade, strategic interest and friendship? Finally, what confidence building measures in the North Pacific would the Government consider putting to the United States and the Soviet Union following Mr Hayden's speech and in the spirit of the recent intermediate-range nuclear forces agreement regarding Europe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to the implication in Senator Vallentine's question, the Government has acted on the proposals made by Mr Hayden in his speech at the ANU conference on security and arms control in the North Pacific last month. Mr Hayden said:

ANSWER.PARA: There are any number of arms control objectives that one could, in theory, seek to have the States concerned set themselves.

He then listed some of these theoretical possibilities, including those mentioned by Senator Vallentine. That is the context in which those particular matters were raised and articulated by the Foreign Minister. Mr Hayden went on to advocate, as first steps, two confidence building measures: first of all, open and frank super-power dialogue on security perceptions and concerns in the North Pacific and, secondly, the release of reliable and authoritative information on force levels and force characteristics and on the strategies these forces are intended to support. Mr Hayden's proposals have been conveyed to both the Soviet Union and the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications in his capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given Australia's abhorrence of the system of apartheid and the Minister's own strong views on the practice, I ask: Has the Government contributed to the Africa Fund to assist the front-line states which border South Africa, many of which are fellow Commonwealth countries? If so, what was the extent of the contribution and when was it made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1986 Non-Aligned Movement Summit established an Africa Fund, to which Senator Watson referred, to provide assistance to the front-line states. This fund is chaired by the Indian Prime Minister and its purpose is to provide broad-ranging assistance to the front-line states of southern Africa to withstand South African destabilisation and to develop their economies so as to lessen their economic and especially transport dependence on South Africa. The Fund met in New Delhi in January this year to elaborate a program of action. The response so far has been substantial, with considerable pledges in kind but few in foreign exchange-in fact, only $US100,000.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is committed to providing assistance to the states of southern Africa. Mr Hayden announced, I hope it will be recalled, a three-year program of assistance to the nine countries of the Southern Africa Development Co-ordination Conference, known as SADCC. He made that announcement on 15 September and the program provided for a sum of $55m. It involved food aid. It also focused closely on training and staffing assistance needs in an effort to assist the SADCC nations to achieve professional and technical self-reliance. So far as non-food commodities assistance is concerned, it also involved particularly some targeted assistance in the transport and communications sector aimed at decreasing dependence on South Africa's transport system. So a substantial contribution has been made by the Australian Government to that particular exercise with the objectives that I have just described.

The matter of an Australian contribution to the Africa Fund is one for continuing consideration by the Government. At this stage, while the Government is broadly sympathetic to the Fund's objectives and while, as I have said, the Government is giving increased aid to the southern African states, it is not presently intended to channel this assistance through the Africa Fund.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. I ask whether the Minister has seen the Press release of 21 September in which the shadow Minister for housing and public administration, Mr Porter, commented on the July figures for housing, claiming:

QUESTION.PARA: While many Australian families want a house, they still can't afford to buy one.
Will the Minister comment on this claim by Mr Porter, and can she say whether it is an accurate picture of the current state of the housing market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have had those remarks of Mr Porter drawn to my attention and I can assure the Senate that they are totally inaccurate. Mr Porter has chosen to quote selectively the statistics of the Australian Bureau of Statistics without referring to the context in which they are set. The use of one month's figures on housing loans in isolation is naive, particularly the use of the month of July 1987. Obviously with an election and a Budget looming and the prospect of falls in housing interest rates, home owners would have been holding off their decision-making.

ANSWER.PARA: The return of the Hawke Labor Government, coupled with a balanced Budget, set the scene for falls in home loan interest rates and, no doubt, these positive results will be reflected in continued and significant housing loan approvals in coming months. The continued high level of housing finance, coupled with falling interest rates, indicates continuing improvement in access to home ownership for Australians. For example, the recent one per cent fall in savings bank interest rates to 14.5 per cent will reduce monthly repayments on a $50,000 loan over 20 years by $37 per month.

The balanced Budget for 1987-88 and the withdrawal of the Commonwealth Government as a net borrower this year will further reduce pressure on the financial markets and help to sustain recent falls in housing and other interest rates. These developments augur well for the ability of housing lenders to compete for funds and to continue to provide a ready supply of more affordable housing finance. The affordability of home ownership will also be enhanced by the Government's decision in March this year to increase income limits for the first home owners scheme, which was particularly targeted to families. Since this Government introduced the first home owners scheme in 1983, over 255,000 Australian households have been assisted into home ownership. In 1987-88 this Government, through the first home owners scheme, will assist a further 52,000 families into homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Given the damage, both actual and potential, of the recent pesticide scare not only to beef producers but also to the Australian trade position, what action has the Australian Government taken to ensure that the standards that the United States of America and Japanese governments have applied to Australian beef imports are applied equally to their own domestic production? What testing does the Australian Government carry out for imports of agricultural products and how do Australian standards compare with those demanded by, for example, the United States?

—I have a note from Mr Kerin on this but I do not think it is really relevant to the central point of the honourable senator's question which, as I understand it, is in short: Does the United States apply the same standards to its domestic supplies, particularly of meat, as it applies to imports? Frankly, I do not know; I will make inquiries about that. If the United States applies to imports standards of something less than Australia applies, obviously that is some sort of anomaly. However, it may well be that the Federal Government in the United States does not have the same degree of control over marketing of domestically produced products as it has over imports. But I will see what sort of reply I can get to that. In regard to the standards applied by the Australian Government to imports of food, again I cannot give Senator Tambling any detail, but I will get an answer as soon as I am able to.

—I draw the attention of the Special Minister of State to an article on page 5 of today's Australian Financial Review entitled `Opposition fights Labor's ID card alternative'. In that article the Opposition spokesman on health, Mr Tuckey, attacked the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, for failing to crack down on tax avoidance. Mr Tuckey also stated in the article that the Opposition would fight any attempt to bring in a numbered identity code which would crack down on tax avoidance and social security fraud. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether a thorough crackdown on tax avoidance and social welfare cheating would be hampered if an enhanced file number is not used?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the variously reported comments of Mr Tuckey about the Opposition's intentions, or at least his intentions, it would seem, to try to obstruct anything that would enable the Government effectively to crack down on tax cheats. There has been some discussion of Mr Tuckey's comments during Question Time today. Speaking for myself and I think for other senators on this side of the chamber, I must say that we are not at all clear what it is the Opposition wants us to do. I know that Senator Chaney and some of his colleagues become incensed when there is a suggestion that the results of their actions protect the tax cheats. But when we try to get from them some sort of idea of what measures they consider are acceptable in order that tax evasion and tax cheating be cut down on, we get nothing but a lot of rhetoric and threats from Mr Tuckey.

ANSWER.PARA: I should make it clear that, despite the decision of the Opposition parties to obstruct the Government's Australia Card legislation, the Government will not desist from honourable and proper efforts to crack down on tax evasion. We have a responsibility to the people of Australia to do something effective about the fact that tax cheats and welfare frauds are costing honest Australians about $900m a year. Simply because the Opposition parties have determined on some populist course of action to prevent us from implementing the most effective means of retrieving that $900m or so does not mean that we will resile entirely from our responsibility to the Australian people. I think that Senator Walsh has made some comments about the currently required use of tax file numbers in the matter of responsibility of employers and so on. The existing tax file numbering system administered by the Australian Taxation Office is to be examined urgently, as part of the package of measures that the Prime Minister has announced to crack down on cheating and fraud. Although the tax file numbering system would not have the same integrity as the Australia Card-that is, it is open to the kind of abuse and fraud to which Senator Walsh and, I think, Senator Chaney referred-it may be possible to apply it in such a way that it will still produce substantial net revenue gains over and above those that can be expected to flow from the other measures already being pursued by the Government. The Government is also pursuing fraud control, cash transaction reports legislation, a births, deaths and marriages register, privacy legislation and the establishment of a Data Protection Agency.

I must comment in conclusion that, although we have heard a lot of huffing and puffing from Mr Tuckey and his colleagues about what they will not allow, we have heard very little from them, if indeed anything at all, by way of serious suggestion as to the steps that ought to be taken to provide some control over the data held on individuals not only in the public sector but also in the private sector. It seems that to this date-like Senator Walsh, I hope to be proven wrong on this-the Opposition parties have decided on a course of total negativism and obstructionism and are not prepared to have a constructive and co-operative approach with the Government on handling what all Australians know by now to be a massive problem of fraud and evasion.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VNG STANDARD TIME AND FREQUENCY SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications: What are the implications of the closure by Telecom Australia of the VNG standard time and frequency service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter that I addressed in my previous portfolio hat of resources and energy. The time signal that was given out by the VNG service was of some utility for a variety of scientific organisations, such as the Bureau of Mineral Resources, within my previous portfolio which were engaged in research that demanded absolute time accuracy. Regrettably, it has been the case that a number of other agencies and private organisations around the place which have wanted to use that time signal have been unable or unwilling to make a cash contribution to keep the service alive. Under the circumstances, Telecom was forced to the decision to terminate the service, it being of no continuing utility for Telecom itself, as part of its new attempt to keep itself streamlined and efficient economically.

ANSWER.PARA: I probably need further information to fully appreciate the implications around the place for all the various people who have claimed to be affected by this before I can fully answer the question, but I believe it is the case that no significant public interest is seriously prejudiced by the termination of the service in question, although it has generated some inconvenience and made it necessary for some particular kinds of time signal data to be achieved by other means. I will see what further information I can dig up on the subject. I am pretty impressed with the extent of the information I have recalled in the last minute and a half, but I would not want to hang my hat permanently on the answer I have just given. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question-in an attempt to help the Minister.
