DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Lewis proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage caused to Australia's international financial reputation and the uncertainty created for manufacturers and investors by speculation about the value of the Australian dollar by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has an unenviable reputation following his comments about the value of the Australian dollar. Almost a year ago to the day, the Minister was telling manufacturers in Australia to make investment decisions on the basis that the dollar would remain at about US62c, and once again, this week, he has been predicting that the dollar will not go any higher than it currently is. Of course, this Minister might well be called the two bob each way Minister because once again-as he always does-he has attempted to distance himself from his own Government's decision. The Minister is a very senior Minister in this Government-I think he is third in line-and as such he is responsible for the Government's decisions. Yet when he thinks that the industry people and the manufacturers in the electorate would not be happy with the actions of the Government, he tries to distance himself from those actions-as one of the political commentators said, as if he were an outsider looking in. But, of course, Senator Button cannot have it both ways. In fact, he is part of the decision-making process of the Cabinet; he is part of the process that results in the dollar value rising or falling according to this Government's actions. Let me quote what the Minister said on 22 September last year at the annual conference of the Heavy Engineering Manufacturers Association. He said to these gentlemen:

SPEECH.PARA: The depreciation of the Australian dollar to a level just above 60 cents to the US dollar has substantially restored Australia's international competitiveness and will provide major opportunities for import replacement and economic growth.
He went on:
Manufacturers should be making their investment plans on the basis that the dollar will remain very close to its current levels . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Which was what, Senator?

—At that stage it was about 62c. The Minister had said that it was about 60c; in fact it was about 62c. It is now a lot more than 62c; it is up around 74c. The Minister told manufacturers to invest on the basis that the dollar would stay at around current levels. The very next day Senator Chaney, who was then the shadow Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, asked Senator Button a question about that statement. Senator Button responded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if the dollar were to appreciate significantly in the next two or three years-
not 12 months, I might point out-
then investment plans they have, predicated on a 62c dollar, would be affected detrimentally.
The Minister then tried to have two bob each way, as he always does. He went on:
I was not in any sense attempting to debate the value of the dollar as at today's level.
Of course he was not; he was just saying what would happen to the dollar in the future. He then went on:
I was concerned to make the point that in my view it is unlikely to appreciate to that extent. There are very sound reasons for saying that.

The Minister, having made that statement at the function the previous night, repeated it in the Senate on 23 September last year. In my first question as shadow Minister I put to the Minister the proposition that this was what had happened. Senator Button said:
If he-
that is, me-
checks his facts-and he can ask me the question again tomorrow-I think he will find I did not make that statement when the level of the dollar was about 60c.
I do not know whether the Minister will argue about that. He went on to say:

I do not in any way resile from the fact that I believe that I said on a number of occasions during last year that my anticipation was that the level of the dollar would remain for some period in the mid-sixties.

The third most senior Minister in this Government is constantly making references to this matter and admitting that throughout last year he constantly talked about the dollar remaining in the mid-sixties. I note that subsequent to that answer the Minister made a personal explanation. On 30 September, just a few days ago, Senator Button was talking to some United States journalists in Sydney. He said:
For a variety of fundamental reasons, I still think the Australian dollar won't go higher than it is now.

Of course, that sent the financial markets panicking. It sent industry into some sort of problem area. While predictions were being made by industry speculators that the dollar would go higher, Senator Button was saying that for fundamental reasons the dollar would not go higher. What was the market response? The dollar fell from US72.4c to US70.7c. Just imagine the losses which occurred among financial investors as a direct result of the remarks made by the Minister. Is it any wonder that he needs to sneak out of this chamber for a cigarette and a cup of coffee? The Treasurer (Mr Keating) was most unimpressed by what the Minister had to say. On 5 October the Treasurer, who was in the United States, told US investors that they ought not to take any notice of any of the remarks being made by this Minister, the third in line in this Government. I quote what the Treasurer is reported to have said in the Age of 5 October:
The only utterances on the exchange rate you ought to be concerned with are those from myself and the Prime Minister-we control monetary policy.

Senator Button might very well say that he was only talking about what the industry might prefer, but that is no excuse. As I have said repeatedly, Senator Button is the third most senior Minister in this Government. Notwithstanding those comments by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, it is quite reasonable for people around the world, whether they be in industry or in financial markets, to note what this senior Government Minister is saying when he states that there are fundamental reasons why no change should take place. Once again the Minister is in exactly the same position as he was 12 months ago.

Of course, in fact the effect of Senator Button's comments of last year in regard to the value of the dollar is only now coming to light. I am aware of the situation of one manufacturer who heeded the Minister's advice to invest on the basis that the dollar would remain just above US60c. I have obtained the permission of this manufacturer to mention his name. The company is called A. Pilgrim Industries Pty Ltd of Victoria and manufactures golf buggies. It is the only manufacturer of golf buggies in Australia that has been able to compete with imported golf buggies on the basis of the Australian dollar remaining at or about the mid-US60c level. Pilgrim, relying on Senator Button's comments, invested some $100,000 on robotics and a further $300,000 on other plant and equipment. Now that the Australian dollar has appreciated nearly to the mid-US70c level Pilgrim is not able to remain competitive on world markets.

The firm has invested substantial moneys because of Senator Button's reckless, in fact even negligent, advice. If Senator Button were in legal practice he would be sued for damages. That company went ahead on the basis of Senator Button's advice and made very substantial investments. It has now lost its world markets because it is no longer competitive. Worst of all, the company now has to start looking to the Australian industry and has to start seeking some sort of tariff protection in order to enable it to survive. As Mr Pilgrim has told me, Senator Button closed his file on that company some months ago. It appears that Senator Button does not care what happens to this Australian manufacturer.

As I said, notwithstanding Mr Keating's denial of Senator Button's authority to make comments about the value of the dollar, on the basis of Senator Button's leadership of the Government in the Senate his comments on the value of the dollar must have authority. Of course, the point is that he should comment more carefully. One wonders when he will ever learn. He continued to make comments about the value of the dollar throughout the course of last year. He was still making comments about the dollar as recently as a few days ago. The net result of those comments last week was to introduce uncertainty and lack of confidence in the foreign exchange market. Financial markets, like manufacturers, need stability. Certainly this is not a quality offered by this Minister at the moment.

Of course, Senator Button's comments reflect the conflicting interests of industry on the one hand and the economy as a whole on the other hand. That conflict was very clearly pointed out by Senator Stone in his question to Senator Walsh today. Notwithstanding Senator Walsh's failure to answer the question adequately it was perfectly clear that at present there is a conflict. Because of the low value of the dollar our assets are seen as cheap to buy by those people with overseas funds to invest. People with overseas funds to invest wish to invest them in Australia by buying Australian real estate. Australian manufacturers are unable to compete on overseas markets even with the dollar at this level, yet this Minister keeps talking about how manufacturers need to take more steps to export their products.

I wonder whether the Minister had some political motives for his outburst when he made these comments. I wonder whether it might be some sort of payback to the Treasurer because the Treasurer managed to take the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) from the Minister by extracting it from the Minister's portfolio and including it in the Treasurer's portfolio. Perhaps Senator Button thought that this was some way of paying him back. Or is there some more obscure motive within this coalition of three Labor parties that we have on the other side of the chamber? We have the right wing Labor Party, the Centre Left Labor Party and the left wing Labor Party. We also have the other part of the coalition-the Australian Democrats. I just wonder whether there is some more obscure motive by Senator Button, some sort of retribution of the right wing faction of the ALP for the right's drubbing of the Centre Left in the recent Caucus brawl. One would not know what this Government and this Minister have in mind.

Recently the Metal Trades Industry Association Inc. (MTIA) predicted that the dollar could go as high as 80c. I ask the Minister: What would be the effect on our manufacturers, primary industries and commodity markets if the dollar reached the prediction of the MTIA? I stress the importance of productivity increases for more efficient production to combat unexpected fluctuations in the exchange rates. I will quote from a letter to the editor in one of the recent newspapers by Professor Wolfgang Kasper. He stated that industry needs an:
. . . overall climate for enterprise and industry rejuvenation by general policies on tax, trade, competition and deregulation of product and factor markets.

I point out that they were the policies of the Liberal and National parties at the last election. I also draw attention to the conflict which has been existing between the second most senior Minister in this Government, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, and the third most senior Minister in this Government, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. Early in 1986 they clashed over the effectiveness of the J-curve. Mr Keating was angry when Senator Button said after the 1986 Budget that there should be additional cuts to spending. Senator Button opposed Mr Keating's taxing of company cars in his fringe benefits tax. Of course, this was the Minister trying to have two bob each way and distancing himself from decisions for which he has a collective responsibility.

The Government having made these decisions of which he has been a part, Senator Button then steps outside and tries in some way or other to distance himself from them. During the election campaign the Treasurer came out and said that the Government would not cut tariffs across the board, but recently Senator Button was reported as supporting such across the board tariff cuts. Some hours later, no doubt having been spoken to by the Treasurer, he changed his mind. I have mentioned their conflict over the Industries Assistance Commission. After the election Mr Keating approached the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to have the Industries Assistance Commission transferred to the Treasury. The Prime Minister did so apparently without consulting Senator Button, who had previously had the IAC within his portfolio. There was certainly major conflict between them on that occasion. One wonders from time to time what is happening because we get Senator Button making comments within the Treasury field and we get the Treasurer moving into the industry field. One wonders who is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce at the moment because Mr Keating has just set up an industry policy section within the Treasury. Now that he is controlling the IAC, he has been critical of Senator Button's lack of speed in reducing industry protection. Having taken control of the IAC, the Treasurer slashed spending on it by 6.7 per cent in the Budget.

In conclusion, in the last week and over the last year Senator Button has sent the financial markets into a panic. From time to time he has sent manufacturers into a panic. He has sent investors into a panic. He has sent the Treasurer into a panic. In fact, the Minister's actions have created a panic button. I refer once again to the first question I asked the Minister in my capacity as the shadow Minister. Senator Button admitted that I may have got him on some sort of debating point. I say to the Minister that I got him that day, we got him again today and I will get him every day until this Government is out of office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I recall that at one stage in my career in the Senate the first speakers on matters of public importance were accorded half an hour. Listening to Senator Lewis, I was very grateful that the time has been cut back to 20 minutes because he was running out as he went on. He had a fairly trite sort of point to make which was gilded by a number of other allegations and was ably supported by an article in the Age by Michelle Grattan. What would we all do without Michelle Grattan? What would Senator Lewis do in a matter of public importance without Michelle Grattan raising some issues for him to raise to fill up 20 minutes? Senator Lewis invited me at Question Time today to speculate about the dollar. Now he chastises me for allegedly having done so.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me set the matter in context before I deal with Senator Lewis's comments. Last Wednesday I had a background briefing session with some American journalists located in Australia relating to a forthcoming visit of mine to the United States of America. During that discussion questions were raised about the effect of the current value of the Australian dollar on the willingness of United States investors to invest here, its effects on various industries in Australia and so on. The conversation began with a colourful quotation from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which he had used a week before that, `if you float the dollar the bloody thing floats'. I think I quote correctly. That quotation was used by one of the journalists who said to me, `I understand that would be your position and, given that, what do you say about the dollar value and its effects on certain industries?'. I repeat-I have no hesitation in doing so because it is a matter of public knowledge-that a number of sectors of Australian industry, particularly those engaged in export activities, had expressed concern about an increased depreciation of the Australian dollar and that many of them had expressed views about where they think the dollar ought to be. That is a matter of public knowledge. The Metal Trades Industry Association Inc., which Senator Lewis quoted, has done so. The Australian Mining Industry Council has done so. As I recall, the National Farmers Federation has done so, as have a number of other industry bodies and prominent companies, such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I certainly indicated to the American journalists that that was the view of some of those export sectors in relation to the Australian economy. (Quorum formed)

I was just setting in context the remarks that I made, on a background basis, to some journalists. Senator Lewis went on to discuss a number of issues relating to non-price competitiveness which I regard as very important in terms of the constituency that Senator Lewis purports to represent as an Opposition spokesman and on whose behalf he presumably moved the motion today. We had a significant discussion about some of those matters. The dollar moves around against various currencies for a variety of reasons. The day that I made the remarks in question it fell 60 points, which was reported by commentators as reflecting a changing sentiment in the market, sparked off by the Reserve Bank of Australia selling late last week, a stronger United States dollar and curbs on real estate investment. All sorts of factors influence the value of the dollar, and I am modest enough to think that remarks such as the ones that I made should not have the effect that some commentators claimed they did.
In the Melbourne Herald of 30 September, the day that I made my remarks, was a report of a survey of manufacturing industry and competitiveness which said:
Australian manufacturers are improving their competitiveness rather than relying on a depressed Australian dollar, according to a survey conducted by The Herald.
The report went on:

Commentating on the survey, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, said the devaluation of the dollar in 1986 showed that Australia needed its manufacturing services sector because the reliance on agriculture and mining was decreasing.

`While initially it may have seemed enough to have a cheap dollar, the longer term lesson of the last two years is that enduring competitive advantage cannot depend on price alone. There will always be lower cost competitors' he said.

It is interesting that the Melbourne Herald reported that as a comment on its survey when it was something that I had said in a speech the week before, and I was unaware of the survey. The survey makes various points about different views among various manufacturers and quotes in particular the view of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, which claimed that the strengthening of the Australia dollar had caused a deterioration in competitiveness in the past six months. Different views were expressed in the same article. I simply make the point that these things have to be seen, even by markets, in some context. I think that my remarks were seen by most of the banks in the context in which I put them.

Senator Lewis raised a number of points with which I ought to deal briefly. First of all, let me make it clear that I do not give advice about the value of the Australian dollar. The honourable senator was quite right to point to a speech that I made to the Heavy Engineering Manufacturers Association a year or so ago which contained some predictions which have turned out to be incorrect. I concede that point. I am not at this stage making any predictions about the value of the dollar, having made that concession to the honourable senator. It is extraordinary for Senator Lewis to come in here and claim that a company such as Pilgrim's made an investment on the basis of my advice, or alleged advice, to the Heavy Engineering Manufacturers Association dinner. He picked an extremely bad example, because Mr Pilgrim's real complaint is that we have lowered tariffs in respect of golf bags. Mr Pilgrim, who is the sole manufacturer of golf bags, has put in a tremendous game on behalf of his company-and invested, as Senator Lewis said, $100,000-in order to get the Government's decision on tariffs reversed. It is extraordinary that the honourable senator should call in aid in the argument he sought to advance Pilgrim Industries, so-called. The company will be readily available to the honourable senator for any purpose he wants. I suggest that he go back there for any advice he wants, because I have no doubt it will give it to him. I would not attach too much importance to that. Senator Lewis went on to pick up on the Michelle Grattan points, carefully culled from her article the other day.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quite wrong. If you look at the article you will find it is very supportive of you. It is against Keating.

—I know. What Senator Lewis seeks to draw from that article is strong differences of opinion between me and the Treasurer about a variety of issues. There have been none-with the possible exception of some misinterpretation of my remarks following the Budget of 1986 about the need for further financial rigueur, if that is an expression Senator Lewis understands. On the question of the effectiveness of the J-curve, the Treasurer and I had a different point of view about that. My view was based on observation of Australian manufacturing as distinct from--
—You were perfectly right.

—I was absolutely right; but that does not matter. The Treasury view was that the J-curve operates automatically in particular circumstances of a devaluation. I think that it might in a country such as Germany, which has an integrated manufacturing sector and where price competitiveness becomes very important in international markets. I never believed for a moment that it would in a country like Australia, which does not have an integrated manufacturing sector. The real difference about that was the question of when, not so much if, the J-curve would operate. I think that it is now operating to a significant extent. But it was not my view that it would operate within three months of a major devaluation, as was being put forward in public at that time.
—By the Treasurer.
—Yes, and by a number of senior bureaucrats.
—There were no other differences? You had no differences with the Industries Assistance Commission.

—None at all. I do not mind where the Industries Assistance Commission finds its resting place in terms of the Department to which it is attached. I was concerned only about the IAC's reports and the manner in which they were dealt with. That matter was not resolved until after the IAC had been transferred to the Treasury. That is a completely different issue from the location of the IAC. I do not have any major differences with the Treasurer on any of these matters. In fact, there are not any major differences in this Government on these major matters. I congratulate Senator Lewis on his efforts in trying to create some, but I do not think there is any substance in what Senator Lewis had to say on that topic.

SPEECH.PARA: There were one or two other issues which Senator Lewis drew upon to try to make that point, but they all fall into the same category. Of course, there will be differences of opinion within governments, between Ministers, between departments, about the emphasis which should be placed on various government policies. There will be differences between departments and between Ministers about what is best in particular circumstances. The question is whether those issues can be resolved effectively. I am not particularly concerned about that. Senator Lewis referred to Professor Wolfgang Kasper's letter. I read the letter, which I thought was a good one. It drew attention to a number of the other non-price factors which affect manufacturing and export activity from Australia. Without Professor Kasper's letter in front of me I cannot give any sort of blanket endorsement to everything in it, but I recall that at the time I agreed with the substance of it. It is most important that we who are involved in manufacturing industry policy should address our main attention to these matters. I have no doubt that Senator Lewis will do so with the passing of time.

Some of the non-price factors concerned with manufacturing include a whole range of matters relating to innovation, management, marketing, employee attitudes and work practices-the issues which contribute to better productivity and a greater degree of excellence in performance. In many firms those things are happening. The process of change is not as fast or as dramatic as one would like, but it is happening. I personally concede that from the point of view of the manufacturer or primary exporter the value of the dollar is important in terms of price competitiveness, but it is in the areas of non-price factors, particularly in manufacturing, that we have to ensure long term competitiveness, irrespective of movements in the currency. Enduring competitiveness does not depend on price alone; it depends on a whole range of other factors which I have mentioned. I hope that the comments I have made put Senator Lewis's proposal in proper context and satisfy him about the discharge of his virtue today in terms of the matter which he felt encumbered to raise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief in discussing this matter of public importance so that the Estimates committees can come on and the Senate can go about its duty, through those committees, of looking carefully at what the Government is doing, rather than spend too much time debating an item which is, I think, of only slight concern. The most uncharitable view that could be taken of the comments of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on the Australian dollar is that which has already been taken; that is, that if the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is able to look at the Industries Assistance Commission, then the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce can look at the value of the Australian dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite frankly, Senator Button was saying that he believed the dollar was overvalued. I am not at all sure that there are too many people in Australia who would necessarily disagree with him. I am not sure that Senator Lewis would disagree that the Australian dollar is overvalued. That statement, in the context of Senator Lewis's proposal, is somewhat odd because a statement such as that-that the Australian dollar is overvalued-is precisely what Australian exporters are interested in hearing. They also believe that the Australian dollar is currently overvalued. When we had last year, with the floating of the Australian dollar, some rather hysterical media comments pointing to the fall in the Australian dollar, anyone looking at the value of that dollar and the need for us to be competitive knew that it would have to fall against the American dollar and certainly against the trade weighted index (TWI), and that its proper value was probably US68c to US72c. We were certainly not looking to having it pegged at the level at which it was pegged prior to its being floated.

Australian exporters were looking to that value and, amongst the Australian exporters, manufacturers in particular were looking to a floating of the Australian dollar which they knew would take it down to that level. In the last few months they were beginning to fear that the rising Australian dollar would threaten their exports and the emerging development of some basic manufacturing competitiveness in that sector of our population. Signs of that have resulted from devaluation and the very considerable wage restraint shown by Australian workers in their responsibilities to the economy. Increased investment has taken place in the form of the purchase of new plant and equipment, although not proceeding at the pace one would wish, and hence the Australian manufacturing sector is looking to investors in industry, and doing so in terms of looking at the value of the Australian dollar vis-a-vis the US dollar or the TWI. In that context I think Senator Button was stating the obvious and was representing the views of the manufacturing sector, which presumably his Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is looking after.

Senator Lewis said that the Minister's statement created uncertainty. With all due respect to Senator Lewis, I do not think it did, as everybody is uncertain as to the value of the Australian dollar and that uncertainty was not caused solely by the Minister's statement. With any float, obviously everybody is uncertain from day to day as to what the value will be. The Minister's statement at most I think could have made some manufacturers aware that the Minister understands the problems that arise as a result of an appreciating Australian dollar. Those manufacturers do not want the dollar to appreciate to a level which would again make them uncompetitive. We need those exports to help overcome our balance of payments problems. If the dollar went down too far that would simply exacerbate the problem and, if it went too high, that would also exacerbate the problems. In other words, we want it within a containable range.

I was rather surprised at the criticism of Senator Button's statement, since I thought-unfortunately I have not been able to check-that quite a number of people had been making statements about the Australian dollar, even those who were engaged in operating in the market-place. I thought Senator Button's comments were tagged on to quite an animated discussion about the value of our dollar, and about where most people concerned think it ought to be pitched. I do not think Senator Button's statement was so important. I hardly see, as Senator Lewis says, Australia's international financial reputation being damaged. If it has been damaged it must have been only in a minuscule sense and we would need a very large magnifying glass to see it.

The types of reports that I have seen in the American Press as a result of Senator Button's statement I think are useful. We have an ever increasing problem with the United States of America, and probably will have a bigger problem as a result of the decision made at the weekend in relation to the free trading operation between Canada and the United States. We have a problem with America's attitude to our market and with the rather supine attitude to the United States that has been taken in some quarters. We must impress upon the US that we will use every available means to keep our share of that market. After all, Australia's international financial reputation-if one is concerned about that-is largely set by US and European markets and I hardly think that either of those two groups is in a position to lecture Australia on trade. Both of those blocs have the most exquisite means of milking the rest of the world to their own advantage and they do not care who gets hurt in the process.

I would have thought that Senator Button's comments would not have done us any harm. In fact I would encourage Senator Button not to talk so much about the Australian dollar but to join the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) and the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) in saying as many hard and harsh things as they can about the United States and the European Community, if we are to maintain even a semblance of reasonable trading operations with those two large blocs, which seem intent on using every available device to destroy our export industries, and particularly our primary commodities, one by one. Quite frankly, I would have thought that that would make a much better topic. It might be that the sensibilities of the Liberal and National parties with regard to the United States are greater than those of some others in this chamber, but in that regard I would refer Senator Lewis to statements made in the United States by Ralph Hunt and the current Manager of Opposition Business in the House, Mr Wal Fife, with regard to the attitude to us that that country in particular is taking. I think that is where the damage is being done to our trade and, ultimately, that is the damage which is being done to our international financial competitiveness.

The last point I want to make is that this matter of public importance comes rather oddly from a party which has as its Treasurer, and presumably its President-to-be, a person who spends a fair amount of time talking about exporting his entire operations from this country and putting his companies off-shore. That, I would have thought, was doing far more damage to our international financial competitiveness. It might also be worth while to look at some of those companies which, after all, have run up 60 per cent of our foreign debt with very little regard to our financial situation. Those are the types of problems I would have thought we ought to be looking at with regard to our international financial competitiveness; and not to some statement-which, after all, was stating the obvious-made to a group of American reporters about where we would like to position our dollar.

I am quite happy to go on the record and say that I think that we should position our dollar round about where Senator Button is suggesting, at around 68c. I think that is round about the place at which it would do us best in terms of the balance of payments and our developing manufacturing trading operation. I cannot imagine that anybody will take any notice of that statement. I do not think any notice was taken of Senator Button's statement. After all, he was talking about what he thought would be the best possible situation. That is what I think it is. I think that his statement followed a lot of others suggesting that that is round about where our dollar should be. I would hope that we could even have a reasonable debate about the matter. If anybody is going to take any notice of these types of things, I would have thought that Senator Lewis's proposal may in fact be upsetting our international financial reputation, given the standing of the Senate vis-a-vis Senator Button.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY REPORTING STAFF

OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS BILL 1987

In his Press releases of 11 June, 30 July and 22 December 1986, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced various operating standards which superannuation funds and approved deposit funds (ADFs) will be required to meet in order to be eligible for relevant taxation concessions. These standards were established following consultations with various interested groups and against the background of the Government's concern to ensure that superannuation arrangements are directed at meeting genuine retirement needs and that members' entitlements are protected.

The Treasurer also referred in his June 1986 statement to the Government's decision to establish a new body called the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to be headed by a new statutory officer. The Commission would bring together the existing offices of Insurance Commissioner, Life Insurance Commissioner and Australian Government Actuary as well as the proposed office relating to occupational superannuation.

The three Bills now before the Senate, namely the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987 give effect to these announcements.

The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987 establishes the conditions and the supervisory requirements which superannuation funds and ADFs must meet in order to be eligible for concessional taxation treatment under the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Bill provides that these supervisory functions are to be performed by a newly created office-the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.

The purpose of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 is to create the position of Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner and thereby establish an Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

The basic objective of the Government's decision to establish such a Commission is to achieve improved efficiency and co-ordination through the integration of the Commonwealth's various insurance, superannuation and actuarial functions. It is also seen as better reflecting the growing importance of the insurance and superannuation industries in the national economy.

This objective is reflected in the Bills before us which rather than adding, as originally envisaged, two additional statutory positions to those already existing, establishes the new senior statutory position of Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner and removes the statutory positions of Life Insurance Commissioner and Insurance Commissioner. The earlier proposed statutory office of Occupational Superannuation Commissioner is also not being established.

The purpose of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987 is therefore to amend the Life Insurance Act 1945, the Insurance Act 1973 and other insurance legislation to remove the statutory positions of Life Insurance Commissioner and Insurance Commissioner and place their statutory responsibilities in the hands of the new Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.

The new arrangements will not remove the legislative and institutional distinctions embodied in the Insurance Act 1973 and the Life Insurance Act 1945. These Acts will remain in force, and the specialist nature of the two industries will also be reflected in the management structure of the new Commission. Thus, the former positions of Insurance Commissioner and Life Insurance Commissioner will be replaced by positions of Deputy Commissioner (General Insurance) and Deputy Commissioner (Life Insurance) in the new Insurance and Superannuation Commission (with equivalent status under the Public Service Act). The proposed legislation allows the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to delegate to these officers all the powers necessary for them to efficiently administer the specialist legislation.
Similar arrangements will apply in the occupational superannuation area with the creation of the position of Deputy Commissioner (Occupational Superannuation).

The Insurance Commissioner and recently retired Life Insurance Commissioner have fully supported and encouraged the Government to adopt the change in approach. They have done so in recognition of the benefits to be derived from the greater integration of the various functions and the difficulties in achieving that objective which could arise from maintaining a number of specific statutory offices. The Government will, of course, ensure that the conditions on which the Insurance Commissioner were appointed will be fully protected.

The status and efficiency of the insurance and superannuation regulatory bodies will be significantly enhanced by the greater administrative and management autonomy, as well as the policy responsibilities, which it is intended will reside with the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The integration of policy responsibilities with the regulatory and industry liaison functions of the Commission will also provide the insurance and superannuation industries with a focal point for discussing matters of concern and should ensure that industry issues are given specialist and co-ordinated attention.

The office of the Australian Government Actuary will form part of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission but the professional independence of the actuarial advice provided by that office will, of course, be fully maintained.
I would now like to outline the particular provisions of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987.

This Bill incorporates provisions to give effect to the handover to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner of the supervision of those non-revenue superannuation requirements currently supervised by the Commissioner of Taxation.

In essence, the Bill provides that, where the trustees of a superannuation fund or approved deposit fund provide to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner certain information on the operations of the fund together with certificates as prescribed, the Commissioner will notify the trustees of the fund as to whether or not the Commissioner is satisfied that the fund has met the relevant standards and requirements for the purpose of establishing eligibility for concessional taxation treatment. Particulars of the Commissioner's notification are to be forwarded to the Commissioner of Taxation.

In brief, these standards, which are to be prescribed in regulations under the Bill, provide for improved vesting of benefits arising from both employee and employer contributions, improved preservation requirements and measures to ensure greater member involvement in the control of superannuation funds and improved security of members' benefits.

Funds will also need to comply with the existing requirements of the Income Tax Assessment Act, pending the passage of legislation expected to be introduced later this year to amend that Act and to relocate those provisions as requirements imposed under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill.

Implementation of the new standards, most of which commenced to operate from 1 July 1986, represents an important step in ensuring that taxation concessions made available to superannuation funds are directed towards the provision of genuine retirement benefits. To this end, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill is an important element in the Government's overall retirement incomes policy.

In developing the legislation, the Government has been anxious to establish a regulatory system incorporating the principle of self-assessment. The arrangements which I have outlined place the onus on trustees to ensure that funds satisfy the operating standards and minimise the degree of interference in the operations of those funds.

This minimal supervisory approach is supported by the measures already outlined to provide greater member representation on the boards of trustees and for a greater degree of audit and disclosure of information to members on the operation of the funds.

At the same time, it is necessary, in the public interest, to provide the Commissioner with powers to enable more detailed checking of the operations of a fund to test its compliance with the standards. Accordingly, the Bill provides that the Commissioner may, from time to time, require a fund to produce documents for purposes of undertaking routine checks and for initiating appropriate inquiries where there is reason to suspect that there may be non-compliance with the operating standards.

The Commissioner is also to be given the power to revise any notification as to compliance or non-compliance that may have been provided if, on the examination of further material, the Commissioner is satisfied that the notification should be revised. As well, discretionary powers are provided to the Commissioner to treat funds as complying with the requirements in special circumstances where the standards have not been satisfied.

The Bill also requires that a statement of reasons be included in any notice of non-compliance the Commissioner might provide and that decisions to notify non-compliance be reviewable. In this regard the appeals provisions in the Bill follow essentially the same pattern as the established appeals machinery in the legislation relating to supervision of the general and life insurance industries.

Under the Bill, where a trustee of a superannuation fund requests that a reviewable decision be reconsidered, the Commissioner will have a maximum period of 21 days within which to confirm, revoke or vary a decision. The provisions will also ensure that upon expiration of that 21-day period (or earlier if the decision is confirmed or varied before then), the trustee will have a period of 28 days within which to apply to have the matter placed before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if the trustee remains dissatisfied with the Commissioner's decision.
Thus the provisions will ensure that an administrator cannot impede the commencement of appeal proceedings through delay in reconsidering a decision.

The standards reflect principles that are well understood in the industry generally and the requirements represent little more than those which should in any case be observed by well-managed superannuation funds. In formulating the standards, the Government took into account the views expressed by a number of bodies on the recommendations in the final report of the Task Force on Occupational Superannuation tabled in May 1983, and on the draft standards released in December 1985 for public comment. The groups which provided advice include the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia and the Institute of Actuaries of Australia.
Consultations with the key industry bodies are continuing as part of the process of drafting detailed regulations to reflect the standards.
The Government believes that there are clear advantages for both industry and government in seeking to have the detailed standards reflected in regulations rather than in the Bill itself.

This approach is consistent with that taken in relation to other supervisory legislation, including in respect of the life insurance and general insurance industries, where highly technical administration is involved. More particularly, it recognises that there is considerable complexity in drafting provisions that will take full account of the diverse range of industry practices in circumstances where that industry is subject to rapid change.

In the Government's view, the formulation of the detailed standards in regulations will provide a reasonable and desirable measure of flexibility to allow the standards to be administered in a way that will facilitate maximum co-operation between industry and government in placing the supervisory arrangements in this area on a sound footing.

At the same time, the approach will limit the extent to which discretions are placed in the hands of those administering the standards and will, of course, allow parliamentary scrutiny of the standards when the regulations are tabled.

I note that this approach has widespread industry support and in this context the Government wishes to acknowledge and endorse the supportive views expressed to the Treasurer by the President of the Institute of Actuaries in his letter of 24 July 1987.

While the Government recognises the considerable size of the administrative task involved in implementing the standards, particularly given that well over 200,000 funds are involved, it is determined that this will not lead to any major growth in staff numbers.

The Government estimates that a total staff of 77 will be needed to perform this work and that most of the required staffing resources (equivalent to 66 positions) will be provided by offsets in respect of existing positions concerned with superannuation functions in the Australian Taxation Office. Thus the significant increase in administrative workload will not involve more than the creation of 11 new positions.

As previously foreshadowed, the Bill provides for the levying on superannuation funds and approved deposit funds of a prescribed annual fee which will be aimed at recovering the normal costs of supervisory operations. It is intended to set such fee at $30 for returns lodged in the current financial year.

The Bill is generally to come into operation on a date to be fixed by proclamation, but earlier dates have been provided for in relation to two matters. First, regulations made for the purpose of relocating to this Act some of the existing provisions in the Tax Act applicable to ADFs are to come into operation on 1 July 1986. Second, the Bill provides that regulations to give effect to the standards announced in the Treasurer's Press statements of 11 June, 30 July and 22 December 1986 may be made with dates of effect foreshadowed in those announcements.

The Government does not see any sound case for deferring implementation of any of the standards as has been suggested by some people. Clearly such deferral would not be in the interests of superannuation beneficiaries and would set aside the important advances that have already been made towards ensuring that employees, as well as employers and other relevant interests have an adequate input into the management and operational policies of superannuation funds. It would also run counter to the Government's concerns that superannuation arrangements justify the relatively high levels of taxation concessions directed to that area. The Government remains firm, therefore, in its resolve to implement all of the announced standards without delay so that the role of superannuation funds will be more closely targeted towards meeting the community's retirement needs.
Finally, it should be noted that this legislation is not intended to set aside the recourse that members of a fund have by way of normal trustee law.

The legislation will also not apply to public sector schemes. However, it remains the Government's intention that public sector schemes comply with similar standards to those applying to funds in the private sector. To that end the Government will be undertaking an examination of funds covering its own employees and where necessary appropriate adjustments will be made. Discussions will also be sought with the governments of the States and the Northern Territory to seek their co-operation in adopting similar standards in respect of funds covering their own employees.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the related explanatory memorandum.
INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSIONER BILL 1987
The purpose of this Bill is to create the office of Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.

As I have already outlined, this Bill together with the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987 and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987 are designed to establish an Insurance and Superannuation Commission which would bring together in one organisation the Commonwealth's regulatory and other functions in the insurance, superannuation and actuarial areas. The statutory responsibilities of the Commission would be centred in the new single statutory office of Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.

The Bill provides for the appointment by the Governor-General of a person as Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner for a period not exceeding seven years. The person appointed is not to hold office beyond the age of 65 and is to be paid remuneration as determined by the Remuneration Tribunal.

The Bill contains provisions to guard against conflict of interest. It proscribes the appointment of a person who is a trustee of a superannuation fund or approved deposit fund, and of a person who is a director or employee of a body that carries on insurance or life insurance business or is itself a trustee of a superannuation fund or approved deposit fund.

The Bill also requires the Commissioner to disclose in writing to the Minister any pecuniary interest he may have in insurance business or life insurance business, a superannuation fund or approved deposit fund, as well as any other business.

The Bill also provides for termination of the appointment of the Commissioner by the Governor-General under certain conditions and for the appointment of a person as Acting Commissioner for up to 12 months during a vacancy in the office or when the Commissioner is absent or cannot perform his duties.

Finally, the Bill provides for the appointment of staff under the Public Service Act to assist the Commissioner to perform the functions of the position and confers on the Commissioner the powers of the Secretary of a department as provided under the Public Service Act 1922.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the related explanatory memorandum.
INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSIONER (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1987

This Bill is one of the three Bills which are designed to integrate the Commonwealth's various regulatory and other functions in the insurance, superannuation and actuarial areas and bring them under the responsibility of a new single statutory officer-the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. The Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 establishes that position.

The purpose of this Bill is to remove the statutory offices of Insurance Commissioner and Life Insurance Commissioner and to effect amendments to relevant provisions in the Insurance Act 1973, the Life Insurance Act 1945, the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984, the Companies Act 1981, and the Public Service Act 1922, consequent upon the assumption by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner of the existing statutory responsibilities of those offices.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the related explanatory memorandum.
